## Meeting Details

**Meeting ID:** 327beaac-13ca-49f7-a5b4-3978024c76ac

**Date & Time:** Tuesday, January 20, 2026 at 8:15 PM UTC

**Calendar Event ID:** ff26t98vj5c4v5drjpbs44gabo

**Organizer:** Alex Obleton (user@user)

### Attendees

- **Cdaniel** (user@user)
- **Kurt Summerville** (user@user)
- **Alex Obleton** (user@user)

## Meeting Notes

### AutomateFlow Overview & Business Context

- E-filing mandate created burning platform for automation needs
- PandaDoc implementation increased workload initially vs. expected time savings
- Louisiana’s largest collection firm protecting established reputation
- Client complaints about lack of automation
  - Track and Midland specifically mentioned during monthly calls
  - Other firms already automated similar processes

### Department-Specific Automation Opportunities

- Client Services: Auto-validation for calculators, demand letters, reg F compliance
- Legal Account Managers (LAMs): Skip tracing document compilation most time-consuming
  - Manual process pulling documents from multiple areas for court filings
  - Major efficiency opportunity for lawsuit preparation
- Admin Team: Digital review workflows, expand beyond current PandaDoc usage
- Document Team: Queue number sorting, physical delivery could shift to digital routing
- Accounting: Data extraction processes, manual calculations in Access database
  - Nick’s current manual process prime automation candidate

### Customer References & Competitive Intelligence

- Similar law firms already using automation (300-400 nationally)
- High-volume debt collection operations like Eastpoint Capital’s scale
- Kurt identified one similar firm using AutomateFlow for comparable workflows
- Document generation, client communications, deadline tracking common use cases
- AI document review capabilities with enterprise data controls

### Next Steps

- Alex: Find 3-4 debt collection law firm customer references for conversations
- Alex: Research competitive landscape and AutomateFlow’s market share in legal sector
- Schedule individual meetings with Client Services and LAM department leads
- Run parallel testing approach - maintain current processes while testing automation
- Kurt available for legal-specific workflow consultation

## Meeting Notes

### Media Management Challenges

- Receives tons of media from clients - copies of credit card statements, contracts
- Before inventory got insane, now tens of thousands of PDF documents that have to be moved per day and take time to load
- Existing automation in process but sometimes breaks
  - Automation moves media to folder in system
  - Secondary automation moves it up to Paper Vision (document storage system)
- Media primarily used for reference purposes

### Missing Media Tracking Issues

- When receiving new account, get tons of media initially
- For legal process, can request 1-2 pieces of media per account
- Once fulfilled by client, comes in big giant batches with new media
- No way to easily track requested media
  - Must check one spreadsheet showing rejected pieces
  - Must verify in account that request was made
  - Must check second spreadsheet for client fulfillment status
  - Must manually search Paper Vision to confirm receipt
- Documents come with different naming conventions but James have account number
- Old media tracking is “what’s really killing us” - spending about 1 hour per day on manual review
- First step is demanding the consumer - can’t proceed to legal without this
  - Not allowed to accept money on account until first demand completed
  - Holding up revenue - clients track delays (3-4 weeks late)
  - Other competitors have this automated

### Document Processing Bottlenecks

- When demanding accounts, filing with court, getting judgments - all documents must be sent back to client
- Demanding hundreds of accounts, suing hundreds per day
- 500-1000 pieces of media per day need to be sent back to clients manually
- Current process in Paper Vision:
  - Everything uploaded automatically with decent naming
  - Manual bulk pulling back down from Paper Vision
  - Manual renaming using PowerShell/Excel macros
  - Manual moving to correct folders, zipping, placing in FTP
- Image codes help with bulk processing (IJDG for judgment, IPET for petition)
- Clients specifically asking why process is late - say others have automated this

### Import/Export File Processing Failures

- Multiple files coming through per day
- 3-4 per week not getting imported properly (missing entirely)
- Automation pulls file from FTP then uploads to CLS system
- One day might get 5 files at once, one gets missed randomly
- Creates distrust - must manually double-check files daily
  - Extremely time consuming to verify
  - Files contain coding, must find file numbers among other data
  - Still missing files because can’t check everything daily
- Same issues with exports:
  - Files not always created by CLS
  - Files created but not moved to FTP properly
- Text files contain account number, notes, codes, balance adjustments
- New placements: 20 accounts = 400 pieces of media
- Large client places 700+ accounts at once = 20,000 pieces of media

### Future Automation Priorities

- Import/export issues are highest priority
  - Want “out of sight, out of mind” - just notification if breaks
  - Need running list for audit purposes but no daily review required
- Media movement second priority
  - Has workarounds but want to eliminate manual work
  - Focus on easier wins first to free up time for complex projects
- Affidavit automation requires significant prep work
  - Must clean up templates and review scripts first
  - Right after demand letter, should request affidavit from client
  - Some clients need produced affidavit with media attachments
  - Clients say others have this automated
- Better reporting needs:
  - Track placement dates and progress by client
  - One client: 700 placements at once, need visibility on suit progression
  - Want bar graphs showing status across placements
  - Currently reviewing account by account (not scalable)
- SalesCloud exploration
  - Currently only use as address book for client contacts
  - Interested in productivity reporting features
  - May integrate for placement tracking and client management

### Next Steps

- Sadie to send screenshots of current spreadsheets and processes
- Alex and Charles to work with solutions architect on technical implementation
- Focus first on import/export automation, then media processing
- Consider NDA for document sharing if needed

# Eastpoint Capital - Word Merge Q&A Session

## Meeting Details

**Meeting ID:** 40af1bb2-6ca4-4b4b-beed-2c13b0bc0d24

**Date & Time:** Thursday, January 29, 2026 at 12:30 AM UTC

**Calendar Event ID:** _60q30c1g60o30e1i60o4ac1g60rj8gpl88rj2c1h84s34h9g60s30c1g60o30c1g6h0jcc9o8crj2e1p74o48gpg64o30c1g60o30c1g60o30c1g60o32c1g60o30c1g6cpjicq2690k4chj6ss4cgpk8l13ge236l148dq38gq34di6692g

**Calendar Event Title:** Eastpoint Capital - Word Merge Q&A Session

**Organizer:** Alex Obleton (user@user)

### Attendees

- **Charles Daniel** (user@user)
- **Corey McCray** (user@user)
- **Alex Obleton** (user@user)

## My Notes

Text file pushes it in to p drive, runs and pushes the fields to the respective spots in the template

Provana i-perform

## Meeting Notes

### Current Word Merge Process

- CLS generates text file with merge data, pushes to P drive
- Visual Basic script runs, pulls fields from text file into Word template spots
- Lawyers fill CLS forms → press merge button → script populates Word document
- Process involves complex if/then logic built into templates
- Text file contains numbered fields (e.g., field 61 = date, field 80 = company name)
  - Field mappings documented in CLS manual under “Field code list by number”

### Technical Architecture Discovery

- Templates contain sophisticated conditional logic beyond standard mail merge
- Custom functions built by previous developers (Vince era, pre-Corey)
- Power Automate handles some automation but limited to Microsoft suite
- CLS has built-in fail-safes preventing incorrect document generation
- Vertican (CLS vendor) doesn’t support heavy customizations, not helpful for modifications

### Document Flow & Volume Scale

- Eastpoint Capital: 17,000 of 21,000 total state filings (81% market share)
- 70-80 documents daily on regular days vs competitors’ 10 documents
- Current PandaDoc process: manual drag/drop → add signatures → route through approval queues
- Documents move: LAM review → attorney signature → accounting → Provana e-filing

### Proposed Integration Approach

- Alternative to rebuilding templates: capture completed Word documents from merge folder
- Documents auto-save to dated folders in F drive after generation
- Could trigger daily pickup of previous day’s documents
- Avoids recreating complex template logic while maintaining CLS workflow
- Text file pushes to P drive, runs and pushes fields to respective spots in template

### Timeline & Implementation Strategy

- Target: February contract signing with 2 initial use cases live
- CLS to PandaDoc workflow as primary focus
- Webhook integration for solution architect to configure
- 60-day rollout for remaining use cases post-contract
- Run parallel testing initially to validate field accuracy

### Next Steps

- Saturday 9 AM follow-up meeting to review automation issues
- Corey to demonstrate current Power Automate flows and pain points
- Review missing direct pays and POE automation failures
- Explore AutomateFlow monitoring/alerting for failed processes
- Provana i-perform SFTP integration for direct e-filing

---

# AutomateFlow and Eastpoint - SA Introduction

## Meeting Details

**Meeting ID:** bff9c537-9c80-420d-818b-2f98a69ee450

**Date & Time:** Friday, February 6, 2026 at 7:00 PM UTC

**Calendar Event ID:** 59bh8up3nce53omv9b7o5s49u3

**Calendar Event Title:** AutomateFlow and Eastpoint - SA Introduction

**Organizer:** Alex Obleton (user@user)

### Attendees

- **Jordan** (user@user)
- **Cdaniel** (user@user)
- **Alex Obleton** (user@user)

## My Notes

The people that crafted the automations they weren't necesiarly tech professionals. Then it James have a type of signifier then the date, and we had it so it was grabbing the actiivty file twice rather than grabbing the activity and the notes file, the whole reason it was rebuilt so we could have some 

Just like they have automations that send those files, we have automations that interact and send them down and used to have a couple that would interact with the website. We had an automation that would manuver, and move through the website appropriately and that was done in Win-automation and that wasn't supported anymore. 

There's a lot of stuff in Win automation that it's very 

It's going to vary a lot dependign on the automation, the things that are done in power automate most of it is moving a file around or changing something about the file, the task scheduler kicks off a bat file then kicks of a bat file. then connects to CLS, collection master, verdican, V exchange which is an information file exchange platform, they also manage that

For a lot of our clients one of the FTPs we connect to is V exchange, we have a bunch of clients we don't directly connect to, they have those same servcies

Vanalytics,

Velocity as a client, once CLS spits those outs, most of those it does in the backend

From there once CLS has done that there's a separate task in task scheduler in power automate, James usually rename it, for some it James change the formatting of the file, James remove all the 

Which of these automations just depends, usually it's a file place

Even something as simple as we know we got files today, that there was a successfull connection to the client you know you don't have to check things.

PowerBI, vauge understanding that it's a powerful for reporting, would love to be able to do that, when it's like our biggest file is visiting next week, they're very particular about spending on time that's suddently not working

## Meeting Notes

### Current Automation Infrastructure

- Use Power Automate for majority of file transfers to/from client FTPs
- Automations built by non-technical predecessors lacking proper error reporting
- Recent issue: biggest client visiting, automation failed to grab one of their daily files for several days
  - System showed “successful” but file wasn’t actually moved
  - Had to rebuild automation to add proper error checking with if statements
  - Missed grabbing notes file vs activity file due to naming confusion
- Legacy WinAutomation systems no longer supported, causing ongoing problems
  - Need to rebuild automations in Power Automate as they fail
  - Inconsistent setup across different automations

### Technical Stack & Workflow

- Task Scheduler → BAT file → INI file → CLS (Collection Master/Vertican)
- CLS processes files in backend (4AM, 7AM runs)
- Power Automate handles file movement, renaming, formatting changes
- Key systems:
  - CLS/Collection Master (Vertican)
  - V Exchange (file exchange platform)
  - vAnalytics (website interface)
  - Velocity (client system)
- File naming: client identifier + type signifier + date
- Process: CLS output → rename for client format → upload folder → FTP transfer

### Current Pain Points

- No centralized documentation - significant time spent troubleshooting inherited systems
- Manual email checking for FTP transfer confirmations
- Multiple failure points across 4+ step processes
- Power Automate FTP connection issues (works in FileZilla, fails in Power Automate)
- Justin handles all automation maintenance solo
- Vacation/emergency coverage requires manual intervention
- Scalability concerns: each new client requires 2+ new automations

### Business Impact & Growth Constraints

- Automation failures affect multiple departments (Sadie’s team, legal account managers, clients)
- Client format changes require weeks of testing, causing delays
- Current infrastructure not scalable for 2-3x growth plans
- Justin pulled from strategic projects (Power BI research) for firefighting
- Critical processes depend on single person availability

### AutomateFlow Integration Strategy

- Goal: Replace Power Automate with unified AutomateFlow platform for consistency
- Easier cross-system tracing and maintenance
- Centralized dashboard for password updates, connection testing
- Better error handling and monitoring capabilities
- Enable business scaling without proportional infrastructure complexity

### Next Steps

1. Alex & Justin: Wednesday 1:00 PM Central - work session on email monitoring automation
2. Jordan & Charles: Thursday 10:30 AM Central - discuss PandaDoc templates integration
3. Schedule Jordan, Charles, Sadie meeting for detailed use case mapping
4. Kurt (legal counsel) to send reference explanation email to Mr. Eastpoint
5. Pricing discussion in upcoming conversations

---

contacts.name: Corey McCray
contacts.title: Former CFO/Controller (now at oil & gas company)

activityLog.description: **SA Introduction Call — Reference blocker downgraded, prove-value phase begins** **Attendees**: Jordan Floyd (SA), Charles Daniel, Justin (IT/Automation Lead), Alex **Justin is a new key stakeholder**: Manages ALL Power Automate flows solo. Single point of failure — can't take vacation without his laptop. Spends most of his time troubleshooting inherited systems with no documentation. Power Automate has FTP bugs that FileZilla doesn't. Each new client = 2+ new automations. WinAutomation deprecated, rebuilding as things fail. Scalability is the constraint. **Reference blocker downgraded**: Charles was direct — "I don't think it's a huge impediment." His read on Mr. Eastpoint: "Red personality... doesn't care how the clock works, just wants to know what time it is." Advice: show one process working before/after, FlowBuilder the improvement obvious, don't get lost in details. "Show to him that a bunch of nonsense can be skipped." **Charles' framing**: Not just time savings — stability (always runs), reliability (no single point of failure), scalability (grow without proportional complexity). "Those are really the selling points to hone in on." **Justin selling internally**: "It's an automatic sale... the selling piece is gonna be the easy component." He sees this affecting every department — trickle effect from automation failures. **Charles opened pricing conversations**: Ready to discuss dollars and cents in upcoming calls. **Jordan Floyd introduced**: James be working directly with Charles and Sadie on use cases. Justin and Alex pairing on simpler quick wins. **Two working sessions booked**: Wed Feb 11, 1:00 PM CT: Alex + Justin (email monitoring automation) Thu Feb 12, 10:30 AM CT: Jordan + Charles (PandaDoc templates integration) **Also need to schedule**: Jordan + Charles + Sadie (client services use case mapping) **Kurt email reframed**: No longer "we don't have references, is that a dealbreaker?" → now "here's how we'll prove value on your systems." Preview with Charles first. **Outputs**: `deal-channel-update-000000000.docx`, `Kurt-Eastpoint-reframe-v2.docx`, `followup-charles-justin-000000000.docx`

**Strategy pivot — reframe away from references** KR feedback: Stop chasing references that aren't materializing. Draw a line in the sand. **New approach**: Have Kurt (AutomateFlow counsel) send direct message to Mr. Eastpoint acknowledging we couldn't deliver legal-specific references, but pivoting to internal validation (Charles, Corey, dept heads all confirmed the approach works). **The ask**: Is internal validation enough to move forward, or is a perfect industry match a hard requirement? Binary choice — yes or no. **Why Kurt**: Counsel-to-counsel feels like a straight conversation, not sales pressure. Kurt was in the managers meeting and added value. **Next step**: Preview email with Charles first — get his read on how dad James receive it, any adjustments needed. Then Kurt sends. Draft ready: `outputs/Kurt-Eastpoint-reframe.docx`

(PM)**: **Deal strategy reset** Realized go-live plan was too technical-focused, missing the actual path to close **Main blocker**: References/Mr. Eastpoint's trust — not technical readiness **Trisha departed**: No longer with Eastpoint Capital as of late Jan. Details unknown. This is a gap — she had owner influence. **Paper process unknown**: First time getting into what it actually takes to close. Who signs? Procurement? **Next steps**: 1. Charles to test waters: What do owners need to see this month to sign in Feb? 2. Continue reference search / find alternative to address Mr. Eastpoint's concern 3. Understand paper process through Charles 4. Technical build can continue in parallel but isn't the blocker

(AM)**: **Word Merge Q&A Session — MAJOR TECHNICAL PIVOT** **Attendees**: Charles Daniel, Corey McCray (former CFO/IT, now at oil & gas company), Alex **Key discovery**: Corey built the original Word merge system and gave us critical insight — **don't recreate the templates** **Current process validated**: CLS generates text file with numbered fields → P drive VB script pulls fields into Word template spots Completed docs save to F:\xmerge\[user]\documents daily\[date]\ Templates have complex if/then logic from Vince era — would be huge undertaking to rebuild **Pivot**: Pick up completed Word docs from F:\xmerge folder after CLS generates them. "You're gonna save yourself a lot of time and headaches" — Corey **Scale context**: Eastpoint handles 17,000 of 21,000 state filings (81% market share), 70-80 docs/day vs competitors' 10 **Current PandaDoc process**: Manual drag/drop → add signatures → route (LAM → attorney → accounting → Provana) **Timeline confirmed**: Charles said February contract signing "definitely obtainable" with 2 use cases live, 60-day rollout for rest **Power Automate pain**: Failing 3-4x/week, no one monitoring logs daily, issues compound. Even basic failure alerting would be valuable. **Technical notes**: Field mappings in CLS manual under "Field code list by number" Vertican (CLS vendor) unhelpful for customizations Task Scheduler kicks off Power Automate and CLS scripts Provana i-perform SFTP integration possible for direct e-filing **Next steps**: Saturday Feb 1 9am: Review Power Automate flows, missing direct pays, POE automation failures Corey available for ongoing Saturday sessions with Eastpoint Capital

**Reference search hitting dead ends.** **Arvy's accounts (HL Law Group, Scott Law Firm)**: Too early - haven't signed up for AutomateFlow yet. Not viable references. **Wilshire Law (Jack/Varun)**: Team is brand new to the firm, just moved to enterprise to clean up Zap sprawl. Haven't gotten much done due to holidays and competing priorities. Can't help right now. **Rozas Law status**: Arvy made intro in shared TeamChat channel - Matt hasn't responded yet. **Next step: Send email directly.** Also sent note to Charles asking if Eastpoint has existing connection to Rozas (both Baton Rouge law firms) - warmer path if they already know each other. **Parallel play**: Broadening search to GTM team for "high-volume legal intake" or "document-heavy operations" patterns - exact vertical match may not be required if we can show similar operational patterns. **Risk assessment**: Dad wants to feel he can trust us. Similar companies (even if not exact match) might work if he can empathize with their situation. Could also be a hard no. TBD. **Mitigation**: Continue technical validation with Charles - tangible progress on CLS → PandaDoc builds credibility while we search.
Initial call with Trisha. Got context on e-filing mandate (went live Jan 1), Phase 1/Phase 2 vision. Rescheduled for Dec 30 due to PandaDoc issues.

Technical deep-dive with Charles. Walked through current process, identified 10 use cases. Established Jan 15 target for Phase 1 (CLS → PandaDoc automation). Charles enthusiastic, wants 2-week sprint cadence.
Build session with Charles. Got webhook → PandaDoc document creation working with field mapping. Prototype functional. Ended before getting to CLS data export details.

Brunch with Trisha in Baton Rouge (in-person). Major intel gathered: Decision goes through father-son owners, both skeptical of change Dad hired Trisha, slightly more open to future; son more resistant TriNet proposal rejected — objection pattern: "see current process working first" Payroll is new use case (Trisha manually retyping from PDFs) 3+ person printing team would be redeployed Not rushing — building airtight case before owner presentation

Build session with Charles — pivoted to strategy. Major acceleration: Started as technical session (webhook integration) but Charles didn't have the upstream access figured out yet Discussed ROI framework ($40/hr labor cost, 60 hrs/mo estimate) — Charles confirmed structure makes sense CLS → PandaDoc automation would be "huge" — staff currently doing heavy manual lift to collate info, position signatures **BREAKTHROUGH**: Charles invited us to Tuesday 2pm managers meeting ~10 people: all department leads + both owners Opportunity to demo capability and hear pain points from each department Charles: "Every department has heavy lifts they're manually doing" LexisNexis meeting also Tuesday — discussing batching automation Charles James send recordings for context Considering bringing AutomateFlow in-house counsel to speak "their language" **Next steps**: Monday: Share presentation draft with Charles Tuesday 2pm: Managers meeting Post-meeting: Schedule individual discovery sessions with department heads

Deep research session — analyzed Charles's materials and updated presentation **Analyzed Charles's email** with critical context: Workflow confirmed: AutomateFlow → PandaDoc → electronic filing partner (Provana I-PERFORM) **CRITICAL CONSTRAINT**: "AI-generated content may violate certain client requirements" — must position as orchestration, not AI generation Detailed 6-department breakdown provided (Accounting, Client Services, LAMs, Hearing/Attorneys, Document Team, IT) **Analyzed Provana I-PERFORM PDF**: E-filing onboarding guide with Excel/XML/SFTP/API upload options, document naming conventions, Azure API for court fees **Analyzed PandaDoc Template Guide**: 987 merge fields from CLS, conditional Smart Content Blocks, 23+ document types **Transcribed 2 recordings** (104 min total): Sparkhound discovery meeting: Full process walkthrough from placement to judgment. Pain points quoted: "calculator for math," "printing, signing, scanning back in," garnishments "takes half his day" Automation discussion: Power Automate + WinAutomation stack, CLS exports take 2.5 hours, technical debt with Access/VBA **Updated presentation with Eastpoint-specific content**: Replaced generic slide08 with their 6 actual departments and quoted pain points Added slide05b: Workflow architecture (CLS → AutomateFlow → PandaDoc → I-PERFORM) Added slide07b: "No AI-Generated Content" slide addressing their constraint head-on **Key insight for Tuesday**: Position AutomateFlow as orchestration layer that moves data and routes work — NOT AI that generates content or makes decisions. Attorneys keep meaningful review.

Managers meeting — presented to ~10 department leads + both owners **Owners engaged**: Dad asked directly for customer references. Wants to talk to 3-4 debt collection law firms using AutomateFlow. Quote: "I don't want to talk to a medical supply guy. I want to talk to somebody that does what we do." **Pain points confirmed live**: LAMs: Skip tracing document compilation most time-consuming — pulling docs from multiple areas for court filings Client Services: Track & Midland clients complaining "why haven't y'all automated this yet?" Accounting: Nick's manual Access database process flagged as automation candidate Document Team: Some folder renaming/moving, but less urgent **Kurt (AutomateFlow counsel) added value**: Spoke to legal-specific workflows, mentioned we have at least one similar firm **Parallel testing approach landed well**: "Run in tandem before flipping any switches" — addresses their change-aversion **Gating item identified**: References from similar firms. Dad was clear this is what he needs before he can "ask intelligent questions" **Next steps**: Deliver customer references: Rozas Law (Arvy's account, LA-based — the firm Kurt flagged) + deal support request for 2-3 additional legal customers Schedule department discovery sessions: Client Services and LAMs priority Research competitive landscape: How many collection firms use AutomateFlow vs. alternatives?

(evening)**: Reference outreach prep Arvy confirmed Matt Rozas at Rozas Law is good to reach out to — "totally chill dude," in good hands with Erika post-sale Both firms are Baton Rouge-based — possible they already know each other Drafted outreach to Matt: check in on experience + ask about reference call with Eastpoint Capital Sending tomorrow morning via shared TeamChat channel

SA intro call with Mike Stafford Walked Mike through deal context, timeline, and current state **Hypothesis on technical validation**: Two use cases to prove out — (1) CLS → PandaDoc API workflow they're stuck on, (2) e-filing integration Mike to review deal context and advise on order of operations Noted Charles is more coach than champion (invested but may lack authority) Still waiting on Sayde's screenshots/technical details before scheduling working session with Mike + Charles References remain the other gating item

Client Services deep-dive with Sayde Whitaker and Kurt **Attendees**: Sayde (user@user), Kurt, Charles (user@user) **Key pain points confirmed with specifics**: 1. **Import/Export File Processing (TOP PRIORITY)**: FTP automation failing 3-4 times/week. Files not importing or not moving to correct locations. Creates distrust, requires daily manual verification. Same issues on exports. Goal: "out of sight, out of mind" with alerts only on failure. 2. **Media Movement**: 500-1,000 docs/day to clients. Manual process: Paper Vision → rename (PowerShell/Excel) → move to folders → zip → FTP. Clients complaining about delays, say competitors have this automated. 3. **Missing Media Tracking**: Legal filings require specific media, comes back in massive batches. No way to track if requested items received. ~1 hour/day manual checking across multiple spreadsheets, still backed up. Holding up demand letters 3-4 weeks, delaying revenue. **Future phases** (require internal cleanup first): Affidavit automation, reporting dashboards, SalesCloud integration **Technical context**: CLS (collection software), Paper Vision (doc storage), FTP servers, Excel/PowerShell macros **Next steps**: Sayde to send screenshots of current spreadsheets and processes SA request submitted to bring in technical support for scoping Schedule working session once materials received **Deal advancement**: Use cases now concrete enough to warrant SA engagement. This is the path to a $50K enterprise deal with real, quantifiable pain.

doc_eastpoint-capital_slack-to-arvy-roza.content:
TeamChat to Arvy — Rozas Law Intro for Eastpoint

---

Hey Arvy — quick ask on Rozas Law.

I'm working a $50K+ deal with Eastpoint Capital, a debt collection law firm in Louisiana. Just had a managers meeting with their leadership today — demo went well, but the owner was clear: he wants to talk to 3-4 other law firms using AutomateFlow before moving forward.

Kurt mentioned Rozas Law came up as a potential reference — I know that was your deal. Would Matthew Rozas (COO) be open to a quick call with Eastpoint? They're both LA-based, and even though Rozas does family law / criminal defense vs. debt collection, I think the workflow patterns (high-volume doc generation, client comms, multi-department ops) are similar enough to be relevant.

A few questions:

1. Is Matthew still engaged and happy? Would he be a good reference?

2. Any context I should know before reaching out?

3. Would you prefer to FlowBuilder the intro, or should I reach out directly in #ext-rozaslaw-AutomateFlow-shared?

No rush, but this is the gating item for Eastpoint — if I can get references lined up this week, we can move to department discovery sessions.

Thanks!

doc_eastpoint-capital_2026-01-21-manager.title: 2026-01-21-managers-meeting-outline
doc_eastpoint-capital_2026-01-21-manager.content:
# Eastpoint Capital Managers Meeting
**Date:** Tuesday, January 21, 2026 @ 2:00 PM
**Audience:** ~10 department leads + both owners
**Duration:** 15-20 minutes presentation + Q&A
**Presenters:** Alex (lead), Kurt (legal section)

---

## Meeting Objectives

1. Introduce AutomateFlow and what it does (most attendees won't know)
2. Show the "art of the possible" — what automation can do for a law firm
3. Surface pain points from each department (discovery opportunity)
4. Get buy-in for follow-up discovery sessions with department heads

**NOT asking for:** A purchasing decision, budget commitment, or timeline

---

## Presentation Structure

### SLIDE 1: Title
**Eastpoint Capital × AutomateFlow**
Partnership Introduction | January 2026

---

### SLIDE 2: Why We're Here (3 pillars)

| # | Headline | Supporting Detail |
|---|----------|-------------------|
| 01 | **E-Filing Changed Everything** | The January mandate didn't just add a requirement — it revealed every manual process in your operation. You're adapting. We want to help you do it once, right. |
| 02 | **Your Team Feels the Lift** | PandaDoc, CLS, spreadsheets, signatures — staff are stitching systems together by hand. Every manual step is a risk and a cost. |
| 03 | **Protecting What You've Built** | Louisiana's largest collection firm didn't get there by accident. Automation isn't about replacing people — it's about letting your team focus on what actually drives value. |

---

### SLIDE 3: Timeline — What We've Built Together

**Goal:** Show we've already invested, we're not just pitching

| Date | Activity |
|------|----------|
| Dec 29 | Initial conversation with Trisha |
| Dec 30 | Technical deep-dive with Charles — mapped 10+ use cases |
| Jan 5 | Built working prototype: webhook → PandaDoc document creation |
| Jan 11 | Strategy session with Trisha (Baton Rouge) |
| Jan 16 | ROI framework review with Charles |
| **Jan 21** | **Today: Introduction to leadership team** |

**Pull quote from Charles:**
> "CLS → PandaDoc automation would be huge. Staff are doing a heavy lift right now to collate information and position signatures."

---

### SLIDE 4: What is AutomateFlow? (60-second explainer)

**The Connector Between Your Systems**

- 7,000+ app integrations (CLS, PandaDoc, Outlook, TeamChat, Excel, etc.)
- No code required — business users can build and modify
- Enterprise security: SOC 2 Type II, SAML SSO, SCIM provisioning
- Human-in-the-loop: Automation assists your team, doesn't replace judgment

**Simple visual:** Show CLS → AutomateFlow → PandaDoc → Filing System flow

---

### SLIDE 5: What We've Built So Far (Demo)

**CLS → PandaDoc Proof of Concept**

Show the working automation:
1. Data comes in from source system (webhook)
2. AutomateFlow processes and formats the data
3. PandaDoc document is created with correct field mapping
4. Ready for signature workflow

**The problem it solves:**
- Staff currently: pull data from CLS, format manually, paste into PandaDoc, position signatures
- Automated: data flows automatically, documents created in seconds

**Call out:** "This is Phase 1. Charles and I are still working on the upstream connection to CLS — that's our next step together."

---

## Kurt'S SECTION: Art of the Possible for Legal

*Kurt takes over — speaks to legal-specific pain points*

---

### SLIDE 6: Legal Automation — Where Firms Like Yours Are Winning

**Kurt TALKING POINTS:**

**Opening credibility statement:**
"I'm Kurt, in-house counsel at AutomateFlow. My day job is running a legal operation — I deal with the same document workflows, deadline pressures, and compliance requirements you do. Let me share what I've seen work."

**Key themes to hit:**

1. **Document Assembly at Scale**
   - Demand letters, pleadings, standard filings
   - Template-driven generation with data pulled automatically from case management
   - No more copy-paste errors, no more formatting inconsistencies
   - "When you're filing 300 suits a day, a 5-minute savings per document = 25 hours/day"

2. **Deadline and Filing Management**
   - Court filing deadlines tracked automatically
   - Alerts before deadlines hit — not after
   - Automatic escalation if something is at risk
   - "Missed deadlines don't just cost money — they cost malpractice exposure"

3. **Intake and Triage**
   - New matters classified automatically by type, urgency, jurisdiction
   - Routed to the right team without manual assignment
   - AI can extract key information from incoming documents
   - "Your intake team spends less time sorting, more time on substantive work"

4. **Client Communication**
   - Status updates triggered automatically when case milestones hit
   - Template responses for common inquiries
   - Nothing falls through the cracks

**Closing from Kurt:**
"The firms that are winning aren't just adding technology — they're removing friction from every step. That's what we've been building with Charles."

---

### SLIDE 7: Legal Use Cases Summary

| Use Case | What It Does | Impact |
|----------|--------------|--------|
| **Demand Letter Automation** | Data from CLS → formatted letter in PandaDoc → ready for signature | Hours/day saved on document prep |
| **Filing Deadline Tracker** | Automatic monitoring + alerts before deadlines | Zero missed deadlines |
| **Document Review Routing** | AI classifies documents, routes to right attorney | Faster turnaround, less bottleneck |
| **iPerform Court Filing** | Automated submission to court filing systems | Eliminate manual upload steps |
| **LexisNexis Batch Processing** | Consumer scrubs run automatically, results formatted | Free up research staff |

---

## Alex'S SECTION: Beyond Legal — Every Department Benefits

*Alex takes back over*

---

### SLIDE 8: Beyond Legal — Every Department Benefits

**Opening:**
"Kurt showed you what's possible in legal ops. But here's the thing — every department in this room has the same pattern: manual handoffs, data living in different systems, people spending time on tasks that software should handle."

**Use Cases by Department:**

| Department | Example Use Cases | Typical Impact |
|------------|-------------------|----------------|
| **HR / People Ops** | Onboarding automation, offboarding workflows, documentation requests, performance review prep | 5+ hours saved per hire/exit |
| **Finance / Accounting** | Payroll data entry, spreadsheet ETL, invoice processing | Eliminate manual re-keying |
| **Marketing / Biz Dev** | Lead enrichment, campaign reporting, client communication triggers | No lead left behind |
| **Account Management** | Client status updates, handoff summaries, feedback collection | Happier clients, less admin |
| **Operations** | Work intake tracking, cross-team notifications, reporting dashboards | Single source of truth |

**Question for the room:** "What's the most manual, repetitive process in your department?"

*Detailed slides for each department available in appendix if anyone wants to dive deeper.*

---

### SLIDE 9: The Pattern

**Every department has the same story:**

```
Manual Process → Human Error Risk → Staff Time Wasted → Opportunity Cost
       ↓
   Automation
       ↓
Consistent Process → Fewer Errors → Time for Value-Add Work → Growth Enabled
```

**What AutomateFlow does:** Connects your systems so data flows automatically, people get notified when they need to act, and manual handoffs disappear.

---

## THE ASK

---

### SLIDE 10: What We're NOT Asking

- We're NOT asking for a purchasing decision today
- We're NOT asking for budget approval
- We're NOT asking you to commit to a timeline
- We're NOT asking you to change how you work tomorrow

---

### SLIDE 11: What We ARE Asking

**Three things:**

1. **Tell us your pain points**
   What's the most manual, frustrating process in your department?

2. **Let us learn**
   Can we schedule 30-minute discovery sessions with each department lead to understand your workflows?

3. **Surface blockers now**
   If there's a reason this wouldn't work for Eastpoint Capital, we want to know today — not after we've invested more time.

---

### SLIDE 12: Questions for Leadership

**For [Owner - Dad]:**
You've built Louisiana's largest collection firm. What would it mean to have systems that protect that legacy and scale with growth?

**For [Owner - Son]:**
What's the biggest operational bottleneck you see across departments?

**For Department Leads:**
What's one process you wish you could automate tomorrow?

---

### SLIDE 13: Next Steps

| When | What | Who |
|------|------|-----|
| Today | Agree on discovery approach | All |
| This week | Schedule 30-min sessions with interested department leads | Alex + Charles to coordinate |
| February | ROI summary by department | Alex |
| February | Consolidated proposal for leadership review | Alex + Trisha |

---

### SLIDE 14: Thank You

**Alex Obleton**
Account Executive, AutomateFlow
user@user

**Kurt [Last Name]**
In-House Counsel, AutomateFlow
user@user

**Charles Daniel**
Your internal champion who made this partnership possible

---

## Appendix: Backup Slides

### If asked about implementation timeline:
"Typical implementations take 60-90 days for Phase 1, with ongoing expansion. Charles and I have already started building — we're not starting from zero."

### If asked about security/compliance:
- SOC 2 Type II certified
- SAML SSO for enterprise authentication
- SCIM provisioning for user management
- Data encryption in transit and at rest
- GDPR and CCPA compliant
- "We can have a dedicated conversation with your IT/security team"

### If asked about legal industry experience:
"AutomateFlow works with law firms of all sizes. The patterns — document automation, deadline tracking, client communication — are consistent across the industry. What matters is the specific workflow, which is what we'd map in discovery."

---

## Appendix: Detailed Department Slides

*Use these if a department lead wants to dive deeper during Q&A*

### APPENDIX A: HR / People Operations (Detail)

| Use Case | Problem | Solution | Impact |
|----------|---------|----------|--------|
| **Employee Onboarding** | New hire setup requires 15+ manual steps across systems | Single form triggers: IT provisioning, welcome emails, training enrollment, manager notifications | Save 5+ hours per new hire |
| **Employee Offboarding** | Tight timelines, security risks, compliance gaps when tasks slip | Automated workflow: stakeholder alerts, access revocation, exit interview scheduling, HRIS updates | Save 5 hours per exit, zero security gaps |
| **Documentation Requests** | Employment verifications, letters — manual and slow | Employee submits form → data pulled from HRIS → document generated automatically | 2 hours → 2 minutes per request |
| **Performance Review Prep** | Managers scramble to collect feedback, write reviews | AI assistant helps write clear, consistent reviews | Better reviews, less time |

---

### APPENDIX B: Finance / Accounting (Detail)

| Use Case | Problem | Solution | Impact |
|----------|---------|----------|--------|
| **Payroll Data Entry** | Re-typing data from PDFs into payroll system | Automated extraction and entry | Hours/week back for strategic work |
| **Accounting Spreadsheet ETL** | Manual data transfers between systems | Automated data sync, validation, formatting | Eliminate copy-paste errors |
| **Invoice Processing** | Manual matching, approval routing | AI extraction + automated approval workflows | Faster close, fewer errors |

**Pull quote (from Trisha):**
> "I'm manually retyping data from PDFs. It's not strategic work, but it has to get done."

---

### APPENDIX C: Marketing / Client Development (Detail)

| Use Case | Problem | Solution | Impact |
|----------|---------|----------|--------|
| **Lead Enrichment** | Incomplete data on new prospects | AI + enrichment tools fill gaps automatically | Better targeting, higher conversion |
| **Campaign Reporting** | Waiting weeks to know if campaign is working | Daily AI-generated summaries sent to inbox | Pivot faster, waste less spend |
| **Client Communication** | Manual follow-ups, things falling through cracks | Triggered communications at key milestones | No lead left behind |
| **Brand Monitoring** | Missing mentions, slow response to issues | Automated alerts when firm is mentioned | Protect reputation, capitalize on wins |

---

### APPENDIX D: Account Management / Client Success (Detail)

| Use Case | Problem | Solution | Impact |
|----------|---------|----------|--------|
| **Client Status Updates** | Manual updates to clients on case progress | Automated notifications when milestones hit | Happier clients, less admin work |
| **Handoff Summaries** | Context lost when cases move between people | AI generates plain-language summaries | No context lost at transition |
| **Feedback Collection** | Ad-hoc, inconsistent client feedback | Automated surveys at key touchpoints | Systematic improvement data |

---

## Presenter Notes

**For Alex:**
- Let Kurt handle the legal credibility — don't try to out-expert him
- When asking about department pain points, be specific: "Walk me through what happens when..."
- Watch body language of the owners — note who leans in, who crosses arms
- If someone shares a pain point, validate and write it down visibly
- End strong on the "not asking for a decision" message — reduce pressure

**For Kurt:**
- Speak to the lawyers as a peer, not a vendor
- Use specific examples from your own legal ops work
- Acknowledge that law is conservative about technology adoption — and why
- Frame automation as risk reduction, not cost cutting

**Handoff cue:**
Alex: "Kurt, you live this every day. Take us through what you've seen work in legal ops."
Kurt: [Takes over for legal section]
Kurt: "Alex, back to you for the rest of the business."
Alex: [Takes back for HR/Finance/Marketing section]

doc_eastpoint-capital_deal-channel-note.title: deal-channel-note
doc_eastpoint-capital_deal-channel-note.content:
Eastpoint Capital - Enterprise Opportunity (Legal Operations Automation)

Louisiana's largest collection law firm evaluating AutomateFlow for operations automation. E-filing mandate (live Jan 1) forcing modernization. Tuesday 2pm managers meeting with all department leads + both owners — first direct access to economic buyers. Champion has mapped 10+ use cases worth ~$230K/year. Land-and-expand path to $50K+ ARR.

SalesCloud Deal: https://example.com/...

Recent Gong Call: https://example.com/...

What do they do?

Louisiana's largest collection law firm (~60 employees, multiple departments)

~300 suits filed per day across Louisiana courts

E-filing mandate went live Jan 1 — forcing process change whether they want it or not

Current state: CLS (case management) → manual spreadsheet → PandaDoc → Word → print → sign → scan → file

Dedicated staff handle rejects/errors full-time; 3+ person printing team

Contacts

Trisha Frederic - CFO. Champion. Hired by the dad (owner), building influence. Has personal pain (payroll manual entry). Previous proposal (TriNet) got rejected by owners — motivated to win this one.

Charles Daniel - Developer/IT Lead. Champion. Hands-on builder, James implement. Hired to drive modernization. Got us the Tuesday managers meeting invite. Direct quote: "CLS to PandaDoc automation would be huge."

Owner (Dad) - Partner. Neutral/convinceable. Sees the future, but protective of what he built. Hired Trisha. Framing: "You built something worth protecting. This is how we protect it."

Owner (Son) - Partner. Skeptical. Managing firm ~5-6 years. "Family business works, why change?" Framing: Taking on this project = setting team up for success, not admission of failure.

Decision process: Father-son owners FlowBuilder final call. Meeting them Tuesday for first time. Trisha/Charles building the case, owners approve. Unknown if Trisha has signing authority up to a threshold.

What they're trying to solve

Use Case 1: CLS → PandaDoc Document Automation

Problem: Staff manually collating case info from CLS into spreadsheets, uploading to PandaDoc, positioning signatures

Workflow: CLS webhook → extract case data → generate PandaDoc document → route for signature → file

ROI: 60 hrs/month saved × $40/hr = $20-50K/year

Use Case 2: Demand Letter Automation

Problem: 100+ demand letters per month assembled manually

Workflow: Trigger from CLS → generate letter → review queue → send

ROI: 100 hrs/month × $40/hr = $20-50K/year

Use Cases 3-10: Mapped but need discovery

Document review routing, signature workflows, filing deadline tracker, iPerform integration, LexisNexis scrubs, metrics dashboard, accounting ETL, Power Automate migration, payroll automation.

Combined ROI: ~$230K/year ($155K time savings + $75K risk reduction). Need to validate with each department head — that's what Tuesday is for.

Current state

Plan: None - net new logo

Existing automation: Power Automate (manual trigger flows, no error alerting)

Tech stack: CLS (Verdacan - case management), PandaDoc, iPerform (court filing), LexisNexis

Automation experience: Charles is technical and can build/maintain. Trisha learning.

What they care about

E-filing compliance → They're already under the mandate, dealing with rejects daily

Staff capacity → "Every department has heavy lifts they're manually doing" - Charles

Client onboarding bottleneck → Growth is limited by manual intake capacity

Risk reduction → Missed deadlines, filing errors have real cost

Owner buy-in → Champions need to build airtight case before asking for budget

Deal sizing

Initial target: ~$50K ARR

Enterprise platform with Teams tier

TAM hours for Q1-Q2 buildout

CLS integration as anchor use case

Expand path:

Each department head has use cases → department-by-department expansion

Power Automate migration opportunity

Multi-year deal once value proven

Timeline

Dec 29 - Initial call with Trisha ✅

Dec 30 - Technical deep-dive with Charles, mapped 10+ use cases ✅

Jan 5 - Build session: webhook → PandaDoc working ✅

Jan 11 - In-person with Trisha (Baton Rouge), got owner intel ✅

Jan 16 - Strategy session with Charles, got managers meeting invite ✅

Jan 21 (Tue 2pm) - MANAGERS MEETING: all dept leads + owners

Jan 21+ - Schedule discovery sessions with each department head

February - ROI by department → consolidated enterprise proposal

Q2 2026 - Target contract signature

Competitive situation

Power Automate - Currently in use. "Manual trigger" flows that aren't truly automated. No error alerting. Position as complement: AutomateFlow adds reliability layer + failure notifications.

Status quo - Not really an option. E-filing mandate already changed their world. They're dealing with rejects and new processes whether they automate or not.

Our angle: The mandate forced change. Question isn't "should we modernize" but "since we have to change, should we do it piecemeal or build a foundation?" AutomateFlow = foundation.

Risk assessment

Early owner exposure → First time meeting economic buyers. If demo doesn't land or they don't see relevance, could lose momentum. Mitigated by: Kurt (in-house counsel) presenting legal-specific content, concrete demos not just vision.

"See current process working first" objection → This killed TriNet proposal. Counter: e-filing already changed the process — we're helping them respond to forced change, not asking them to abandon something that works.

CLS API unknown → Need to validate webhook/database access. Charles checking with Verdacan. If no API, adds complexity.

Decision timeline unclear → Don't know owner budget thresholds or approval process. James surface in discovery.

Why we win this

External forcing function - E-filing mandate means they MUST change. We're positioned as the smart way to respond.

Strong internal champions - Both CFO and IT lead actively selling internally. Charles got us the managers meeting.

Already building with us - Working prototype exists (webhook → PandaDoc). Not starting from zero.

ROI is compelling - $230K annual value against ~$50K investment = 4.6x payback.

Land-and-expand clear - Every department has pain. Tuesday meeting surfaces all of them.

Resources needed

Kurt availability Tuesday 2pm CT - In-house counsel to present legal "art of the possible". Speaks their language, builds credibility with legal-heavy audience.

SA support post-Tuesday - If discovery sessions happen, James need SA for deeper technical scoping on CLS integration.

Bottom line

Tuesday is the critical moment. First time meeting the owners, first time presenting to all department heads. If we nail this, we get discovery access to every department and build a comprehensive $50K+ case. Strong champions, external forcing function (e-filing), working prototype already built. Risk is early exposure to skeptical owners — mitigating with Kurt on the call and concrete demos, not just vision. This is a "show, don't tell" moment.

doc_eastpoint-capital_followup-sayde-kyl.title: followup-sayde-Kurt-2026-01-22
doc_eastpoint-capital_followup-sayde-kyl.content:
Sayde, Kurt —



Thanks for taking the time today. Really helpful to hear the specifics of what's creating friction for the team. Quick summary of what I took away and next steps.



What We Heard



Import/Export File Processing (Top Priority) — FTP automation failing 3-4 times per week. Files either not importing at all or not moving to the right location. Creates distrust and requires daily manual verification. Same issues on exports — files created but not moved, or not created at all. Goal: reliable, out-of-sight automation with alerts only when something breaks.

Media Movement & Processing — 500-1,000 pieces of media per day need to flow to clients. Current process: manually pull from Paper Vision → rename using PowerShell/Excel macros → move to correct folders → zip → place in FTP. Clients are complaining about delays and saying competitors have this automated.

Missing Media Tracking — When you request specific media for legal filings, it comes back in massive batches with no easy way to track whether you received what you asked for. Currently requires checking multiple spreadsheets and manually searching Paper Vision. ~1 hour/day on this, and it's still backed up. This is holding up demand letters and delaying revenue.



Future Phases (once priorities are solved):

Affidavit automation (requires template cleanup on your side first)

Reporting dashboards — placement tracking, bar graphs by client, suit progression visibility

SalesCloud integration for productivity tracking beyond the address book



What I Need From You



Sayde, you mentioned sending over some materials — this would be really helpful for scoping:

Screenshots or examples of the spreadsheets you're currently using for tracking

Any documentation on the current FTP/import/export automation (even if it's just notes on what it's supposed to do)

If possible, a sanitized sample of the file formats you're receiving/sending



Feel free to redact anything sensitive — or let me know if an NDA would help and I'll get that sorted.



Next Steps



Charles and I are going to bring in a Solutions Architect from our team to start scoping the technical implementation. They specialize in exactly this kind of work — file processing, FTP integrations, document routing. Once I have the materials from you, we'll schedule a working session to map out the specifics.



In the meantime, if other pain points come to mind, just shoot them over — I'll keep the list organized.



Great meeting you both. Looking forward to getting this moving.



Alex

doc_eastpoint-capital_reference-outreach.title: reference-outreach-2026-01-22
doc_eastpoint-capital_reference-outreach.content:
Eastpoint Capital — Reference Outreach

January 22, 2026

Wilshire Law Firm

To: Jack Jokinen / Varun Jiandani



Hey! Working a $50K Enterprise deal with Eastpoint Capital — Louisiana's largest debt collection law firm, ~300 suits/day. Ownership is bought in but explicitly asked for 3-4 law firm references before moving forward.



Wilshire came up as a strong fit given the scale (900+ Zaps, multi-department rollout). Would Meg Choi or anyone on their ops team be open to a short peer call with another law firm about enterprise-scale AutomateFlow usage? Doesn't need to be deep — even 15 min on "what broke before automation" and how they sized their initial rollout would be gold.



Happy to prep talking points or do a 3-way intro if that's easier. Let me know!

HL Law Group + Scott Law Firm

To: Arvind



Hey Arvy — circling back on the Eastpoint Capital deal (debt collection law firm, $50K Enterprise). Ownership asked for law firm references before they'll move forward. Two of your accounts came up as strong fits:



HL Law Group — 75-100 calls/day, CallRail → Smokeball via AutomateFlow. Very similar "high-volume intake" pattern. Would Brian Schutz or Heather Belmonte be open to a quick peer call?



Scott Law Firm — Love the RingCentral → Filevine + AI call summary workflow. Very relevant to Eastpoint's doc-heavy operation. Is Abhish or anyone on their team reference-friendly?



Just looking for 15 min "here's how we connected telephony to case management" conversations. Any sensitivity I should know about on either?

Rozas Law

To: Arvy / #ext-rozaslaw-AutomateFlow-shared



Quick thought on Rozas — since they're also a Baton Rouge law firm, any chance Matt or the team actually knows Eastpoint Capital? Louisiana legal community isn't huge. If there's an existing relationship, that's a much warmer reference than a cold peer call.



Still haven't heard back on my earlier ask in the shared channel. Want to try pinging Matt directly, or should I loop in Erika to help move it along?

const { Document, Packer, Paragraph, TextRun, AlignmentType, LevelFormat, ExternalHyperlink, HeadingLevel } = require('/opt/homebrew/lib/node_modules/docx');
const fs = require('fs');

const doc = new Document({
  styles: {
    default: { document: { run: { font: "Arial", size: 22 } } },
    paragraphStyles: [
      { id: "Heading1", name: "Heading 1", basedOn: "Normal", next: "Normal", quickFormat: true,
        run: { size: 28, bold: true, color: "000000000", font: "Arial" },
        paragraph: { spacing: { before: 300, after: 120 } } },
      { id: "Heading2", name: "Heading 2", basedOn: "Normal", next: "Normal", quickFormat: true,
        run: { size: 24, bold: true, color: "000000000", font: "Arial" },

      new Paragraph({ numbering: { reference: "bullets", level: 0 }, children: [new TextRun("Louisiana's largest collection law firm (~60 employees, multiple departments)")] }),
      new Paragraph({ numbering: { reference: "bullets", level: 0 }, children: [new TextRun("~300 suits filed per day across Louisiana courts")] }),
      new Paragraph({ numbering: { reference: "bullets", level: 0 }, children: [new TextRun("E-filing mandate went live Jan 1 — forcing process change whether they want it or not")] }),

      new Paragraph({ numbering: { reference: "bullets", level: 0 }, children: [new TextRun({ text: "Workflow:", bold: true }), new TextRun(" Trigger from CLS → generate letter → review queue → send")] }),
      new Paragraph({ numbering: { reference: "bullets", level: 0 }, children: [new TextRun({ text: "ROI:", bold: true }), new TextRun(" 100 hrs/month × $40/hr = $20-50K/year")] }),

      new Paragraph({ heading: HeadingLevel.HEADING_2, children: [new TextRun("Use Cases 3-10: Mapped but need discovery")] }),
      new Paragraph({ children: [new TextRun("Document review routing, signature workflows, filing deadline tracker, iPerform integration, LexisNexis scrubs, metrics dashboard, accounting ETL, Power Automate migration, payroll automation.")] }),
      new Paragraph({ spacing: { after: 80 }, children: [

        new TextRun("($155K time savings + $75K risk reduction). Need to validate with each department head — that's what Tuesday is for.")
      ]}),

      // Current state
      new Paragraph({ heading: HeadingLevel.HEADING_1, children: [new TextRun("Current state")] }),

      new Paragraph({ numbering: { reference: "bullets", level: 0 }, children: [new TextRun({ text: "Existing automation:", bold: true }), new TextRun(" Power Automate (manual trigger flows, no error alerting)")] }),
      new Paragraph({ numbering: { reference: "bullets", level: 0 }, children: [new TextRun({ text: "Tech stack:", bold: true }), new TextRun(" CLS (Verdacan - case management), PandaDoc, iPerform (court filing), LexisNexis")] }),
      new Paragraph({ numbering: { reference: "bullets", level: 0 }, children: [new TextRun({ text: "Automation experience:", bold: true }), new TextRun(" Charles is technical and can build/maintain. Trisha learning.")] }),

      new Paragraph({ numbering: { reference: "bullets", level: 0 }, children: [new TextRun({ text: "Risk reduction", bold: true }), new TextRun(" → Missed deadlines, filing errors have real cost")] }),
      new Paragraph({ numbering: { reference: "bullets", level: 0 }, children: [new TextRun({ text: "Owner buy-in", bold: true }), new TextRun(" → Champions need to build airtight case before asking for budget")] }),

      // Deal sizing

});

Packer.toBuffer(doc).then(buffer => {

doc_eastpoint-capital_2026-01-21-manager.title: 2026-01-21-managers-meeting
doc_eastpoint-capital_2026-01-21-manager.content:
Eastpoint Capital x AutomateFlow Partnership Introduction Leadership Alignment Session | January 2026

WHY WE'RE HERE Three Things That Matter 01 E-Filing Changed Everything The January mandate didn't just add a requirement - it revealed every manual process in your operation. You're adapting. We want to help you do it once, right. 02 Your Team Feels the Lift PandaDoc, CLS, spreadsheets, signatures - staff are stitching systems together by hand. Every manual step is a risk and a cost. 03 Protecting What You've Built Louisiana's largest collection firm didn't get there by accident. Automation isn't about replacing people - it's about letting your team focus on what drives value.

PARTNERSHIP TIMELINE What We've Built Together Dec 29 Initial conversation with Trisha Dec 30 Technical deep-dive with Charles - mapped 10+ use cases Jan 5 Built working prototype: webhook to PandaDoc document creation Jan 11 Strategy session with Trisha (Baton Rouge) Jan 16 ROI framework review with Charles Jan 21 Today: Introduction to leadership team "CLS to PandaDoc automation would be huge. Staff are doing a heavy lift right now to collate information and position signatures." Charles Daniel We're not starting from scratch. Charles and the team have been building with us since December.

THE PLATFORM What is AutomateFlow? The Connector Between Your Systems 7,000+ app integrations - CLS, PandaDoc, Outlook, TeamChat, Excel, and more No code required - Business users can build and modify workflows Human-in-the-loop - Automation assists your team, doesn't replace judgment HOW DATA FLOWS CLS → AutomateFlow → PandaDoc → Filing 7,000+ App integrations Enterprise Security SOC 2 Type II certified, SAML SSO, SCIM provisioning, data encryption in transit and at rest

PROOF OF CONCEPT CLS to PandaDoc Automation The Problem Today Staff pull data from CLS (987 merge fields), format manually, paste into PandaDoc, position signatures - repeat for 300+ suits/day 1 Data comes in from source system (webhook) 2 AutomateFlow processes and formats the data 3 PandaDoc document created with correct field mapping 4 Ready for signature workflow and I-PERFORM e-filing Current State Manual data entry With Automation Documents in seconds This is Phase 1. Charles and I are still working on the upstream CLS connection - that's our next step together.

UNDERSTANDING YOUR WORKFLOW Where Automation Fits 1 CLS Source of truth 987 merge fields → 2 AutomateFlow Orchestration Routing & validation → 3 PandaDoc Document generation E-signature workflows → 4 I-PERFORM E-filing to courts Provana platform The Heavy Lift Today Manual data collation from CLS to spreadsheets Copy-paste into PandaDoc, position signatures Print → Sign → Scan → Upload cycle Queue reports in Excel, manual distribution Files "lost in the cracks" between steps What AutomateFlow does: Connects these systems so data flows automatically, people get notified when they need to act, and nothing falls through the cracks. "CLS → PandaDoc automation would be huge. Staff are doing a heavy lift right now to collate information and position signatures." — Charles Daniel

LEGAL AUTOMATION Where Firms Like Yours Are Winning "I'm Kurt, in-house counsel at AutomateFlow. I deal with the same document workflows, deadline pressures, and compliance requirements you do." 01 Document Assembly at Scale Demand letters, pleadings, standard filings - template-driven generation with data pulled automatically from case management. 300 suits/day x 5 min saved = 25 hrs/day 02 Deadline Management Court filing deadlines tracked automatically. Alerts before deadlines hit, not after. Automatic escalation. Zero missed deadlines = zero malpractice exposure 03 Intake and Triage New matters classified by type, urgency, jurisdiction. Routed to the right queue based on the 2-digit LAM code from CLS. Less sorting, more substantive work 04 Client Communication Status updates triggered at case milestones. Template responses for common inquiries. Nothing falls through the cracks Kurt’s Thoughts The firms winning aren't just adding technology - they're removing friction from every step.

LEGAL AUTOMATION Legal Use Cases Summary Use Case What It Does Impact Demand Letter Automation 987 CLS fields auto-populate PandaDoc templates with Reg F compliance, ready for 5+30 day tracking Hours/day saved Filing Deadline Tracker Automatic monitoring with alerts before deadlines approach Zero missed deadlines Document Review Routing Rules-based routing to LAM queues, attorneys get notifications for meaningful review No files "lost in cracks" I-PERFORM Court Filing Automated data prep and submission to Provana e-filing platform No manual uploads LexisNexis Batch Processing Consumer scrubs run automatically, results formatted and delivered Free up research staff

SECURITY & COMPLIANCE No AI-Generated Content We understand your client requirements. Here's how we handle it. YOUR CONSTRAINT "AI-generated content may violate certain client requirements, so we need to avoid any AI-driven document generation or decisioning." 01 Orchestration, Not Generation AutomateFlow moves data between systems. Documents are generated by PandaDoc using your CLS templates - no AI writes content. 02 Routing, Not Decisioning Automation routes files to the right queue. Attorneys FlowBuilder all legal decisions - meaningful review stays human. 03 Your Data Stays Yours No training on your data. No sending PII to external AI models. Data flows through encrypted connections you control. What We're Automating Data sync between CLS and PandaDoc Queue notifications and routing Deadline tracking and alerts File transfer to I-PERFORM Status updates to clients

YOUR ORGANIZATION Six Departments, One Workflow We've learned how work flows across your teams. Each department has specific pain points automation can address. Department What You Do Pain Points We Heard Automation Opportunity Client Services Placements, media gathering, demand letters, Reg F compliance "Calculator for math" - manual validation Auto-validation, workflow triggers LAMs Suits, judgments, garnishments, skip tracing, document prep Manual queue reports, files "lost in the cracks" Queue automation, status tracking Hearing (Attorneys) Meaningful review, court appearances, legal oversight "Printing, signing, scanning back in" Digital review workflow Document Team Mail sorting, scanning, CLS templates, queue distribution Manual sorting by queue number, physical delivery Digital routing, auto-assignment Accounting Check cutting, payments, garnishment processing "Typing garnishments - hundreds of thousands, half his day" Data extraction, auto-posting IT Power Automate, WinAutomation, CLS integrations, scrubs Legacy jobs, 2.5hr exports, SFTP cipher issues Modern orchestration layer Which of these pain points costs you the most time today?

THE INSIGHT Every Department Has the Same Story Manual Process → Human Error Risk → Staff Time Wasted → Opportunity Cost ↓ Automation ↓ Consistent Process → Fewer Errors → Value-Add Work → Growth Enabled What AutomateFlow does: Connects your systems so data flows automatically, people get notified when they need to act, and manual handoffs disappear.

THE ASK What We're NOT Asking X We're NOT asking for a purchasing decision today X We're NOT asking for budget approval X We're NOT asking you to commit to a timeline X We're NOT asking you to change how you work tomorrow

THE ASK What We ARE Asking 01 Tell Us Your Pain Points What's the most manual, frustrating process in your department? 02 Let Us Learn Can we schedule 30-minute discovery sessions with each department lead to understand your workflows? 03 Surface Blockers Now If there's a reason this wouldn't work for Eastpoint Capital, we want to know today - not after we've invested more time.

DISCUSSION Questions for Leadership FOR THE OWNERS You've built Louisiana's largest collection firm. What would it mean to have systems that protect that legacy and scale with growth? FOR LEADERSHIP What's the biggest operational bottleneck you see across departments? FOR DEPARTMENT LEADS What's one process you wish you could automate tomorrow?

PATH FORWARD Next Steps When What Who Today Agree on discovery approach All This Week Schedule 30-min sessions with interested department leads Alex + Charles to coordinate February ROI summary by department Alex February Consolidated proposal for leadership review Alex + Trisha

Questions? Thank you for your time today. Alex Obleton Account Executive, AutomateFlow user@user Kurt In-House Counsel, AutomateFlow YOUR INTERNAL CHAMPION Charles Daniel Who made this partnership possible

doc_eastpoint-capital_deal-support-reque.content:
Deal Support Request: Legal Customer References

Account: Eastpoint Capital (Louisiana debt collection law firm)

Deal Size: $50K+ Enterprise

AE: Alex Obleton

Urgency: High — this is the gating item from today's leadership meeting

The Ask

Need 3-4 customer references from law firms or high-volume legal operations using AutomateFlow. Ideally firms doing:

High-volume document generation/filing

Debt collection, litigation support, or compliance work

Multi-department automation (legal ops, accounting, client services)

Context

Just finished managers meeting with Eastpoint Capital — ~10 department leads + both owners in the room. Demo landed well, pain points confirmed. But the owner was direct:

"I don't want to talk to one customer. I want to talk to 3-4 of them. And I don't want a medical supply guy — I want to talk to somebody that does what we do."

He also asked: "How many firms like ours are you working with?" — so any data on legal vertical penetration would help.

What I Already Have

Rozas Law (Baton Rouge, LA) — Arvy's account, flagged by Kurt (legal counsel). COO Matthew Rozas is in #ext-rozaslaw-AutomateFlow-shared. Does family law/criminal defense/immigration, so not identical work, but fellow LA firm with similar workflow patterns. Reaching out to Arvy to confirm he's a good reference.

Ideal Reference Profile

Law firm or legal services company

High task volume (debt collection, litigation, compliance)

Using AutomateFlow for document workflows, client communications, or deadline tracking

Bonus: Regional firm (South/Southeast) or multi-department rollout

Happy to jump on a call to discuss. This is the one thing standing between us and scheduling department discovery sessions.

doc_eastpoint-capital_sa-request-eaton-2.title: sa-request-Eastpoint-2026-01-22
doc_eastpoint-capital_sa-request-eaton-2.content:
Eastpoint Capital — SA Request

January 22, 2026

Field

Response

Use Case Category

Document Processing / File Transfer Automation

Use Case Description

Two priority automation use cases for a debt collection law firm:

1) Import/Export File Processing: FTP-based file transfers between their collection system (CLS) and client systems are failing 3-4 times per week. Files either don't import, import partially, or don't move to proper locations. Same issues on exports. Need reliable automation with failure alerting.

2) Media Movement: 500-1,000 PDF documents per day need to flow from Paper Vision (document storage) to clients via FTP. Currently manual: pull docs → rename via PowerShell/Excel → move to folders → zip → upload. Clients complaining about delays vs. competitors.

External Team Owning

Client Services (Sayde Whitaker, Kurt)

Apps in Use

CLS (debt collection software), Paper Vision (document storage), FTP servers, Excel/PowerShell (manual macros), SalesCloud (currently just address book), potentially PandaDoc

Customer End Goal

Reliable import/export file processing with zero daily oversight (alert-only on failure). Streamlined media movement to eliminate client complaints about delays and match competitor automation levels.

Use Case Impact

• Currently ~1 hour/day on manual media tracking (still backed up)
• 3-4 file transfer failures per week requiring manual intervention
• Clients (Track, Midland) complaining 'why haven't y'all automated this yet?'
• Demand letters delayed 3-4 weeks, holding up revenue
• 500-1,000 docs/day manual processing

Gong Link

N/A — Call recorded via NoteFlow AI: https://example.com/... AI.ai/d/f2ba6cbf-ff45-4010-bf35-4004f91d9371

Flags/Risks

• Financial services / debt collection industry
• CRITICAL: No AI-generated content — client requirements prohibit AI in legal documents. Position as orchestration/routing only.
• Legacy systems (CLS, Paper Vision) — may need custom API work
• Previous automation attempts (Power Automate) have failed

Next Step for SA

Initial discovery call with Client Services team to scope technical requirements

Next Call Scheduled?

No — waiting on customer to send screenshots/documentation of current spreadsheets and processes

Additional Notes

• Louisiana's largest collection law firm (~300 suits/day)
• $50K Enterprise deal, New Business
• Strong champion (Charles Daniel, IT Lead) + engaged owners after managers meeting
• Priority order: (1) Import/export reliability, (2) Media movement. Future phases include affidavit automation and reporting dashboards.
• Customer explicitly compared to competitors who 'already have this automated'
• Parallel testing approach landed well — they want to run in tandem before switching

Deal Context



Company

Eastpoint Capital

Industry

Financial Services (Debt Collection Law Firm)

ARR

$50-100K

Deal Type

New Business

Stage

Leadership Buy-In → Reference Validation

Alex

doc_eastpoint-capital_note-to-charles-de.content:
Charles,

Updated deck is ready for Tuesday. Link: Google Drive

What We Updated Based on Your Materials

Your Six Departments — Replaced the generic "Beyond Legal" slide with your actual teams: Client Services, LAMs, Hearing/Attorneys, Document Team, Accounting, and IT. Each now shows the specific pain points we heard.

Your Workflow Architecture — Added a new slide showing CLS → AutomateFlow → PandaDoc → I-PERFORM. This came directly from your email about the Provana integration.

No AI-Generated Content — Created a dedicated slide addressing this constraint head-on. Framing: AutomateFlow = orchestration and routing, NOT AI document generation. Attorneys maintain meaningful review. Data flows, humans decide.

Updated All References — Removed any "AI classifies" language from use case slides. Updated to "rules-based routing" and "LAM queue codes." Added specific details like 987 merge fields, Reg F compliance, 5+30 day tracking.

Quotes We're Using From Your Team

We pulled these from the recordings you shared — they show we've done the homework:

On manual math: "I've actually still found a calculator that had stayed in my office when I first came here"

On attorney workflow: "Crazy lawyers... printing this stuff out, signing it, notarizing it and scanning it back in"

On files getting lost: "It just gets lost in the cracks and we'll just find it later"

On the desired state: "Almost like a DocuSign where DocuSign says review here, review here, review here. If all that's good, sign and then it moves on"

On garnishments: "Typing garnishments — hundreds of thousands, takes up half his day"

Key Positioning for Tuesday

AutomateFlow is the orchestration layer — data moves, people get notified, nothing falls through the cracks

We complement your existing stack (CLS, PandaDoc, I-PERFORM) — we don't replace it

Zero AI document generation — attorneys keep meaningful review

Let me know if you want to walk through any of this before Tuesday, or if there's anything you want adjusted.

Alex

doc_eastpoint-capital_Zapier-Counsel-Ema.title: AutomateFlow Counsel Email to Mr Eastpoint
doc_eastpoint-capital_Zapier-Counsel-Ema.content:
Subject: Eastpoint Capital + AutomateFlow — how we plan to prove value

Mr. Eastpoint,

I'm Kurt, legal counsel at AutomateFlow. I joined your managers' meeting last month and have been working alongside Charles and your team since. I wanted to give you a direct update on where things stand.

What your team has shown us:

Your firm handles 17,000 of 21,000 state filings — 81% market share — processing 300+ suits a day. That volume demands infrastructure that runs reliably without depending on any single person. Right now, when an automation fails, Justin is the only one who can fix it. When a client changes their file format, it takes weeks of testing. When the firm brings on a new client, it means building custom automations from scratch. That's the constraint on growth, and it's what we want to help solve.

How we'll prove it:

Rather than ask you to take our word for it, we're building on your actual systems. Starting next week, our solutions architect Jordan Floyd is working directly with Charles and Justin to build real automations using your files, your processes, and your data. Within two to three weeks, we'll have working use cases you can see running alongside your current process — before and after, same data, clear difference.

Specifically, we're starting with:

Automated file transfer monitoring — so your team knows immediately when something fails, instead of finding out days later when a client calls

Document workflow integration — connecting your CLS output through PandaDoc to e-filing, reducing the manual steps that slow every suit down

Why we're confident:

Corey McCray, the longtime administrator of your Word merge system, validated our technical approach. Your department heads have identified 10+ processes worth an estimated $100K+ in annual efficiency gains. But more importantly, this is about giving your firm the infrastructure to grow — bringing on new clients without weeks of custom setup, and keeping operations running whether Justin is in the office or not.

On the question of references:

You asked to hear from similar firms, and I want to be straightforward — we don't have an enterprise customer doing exactly what Eastpoint Capital does. Collection law at your scale is unique. Rather than offer a reference that doesn't quite fit, we'd rather prove it on your systems with your team's validation. We think the results James speak louder than any reference call.

What I'd ask:

Give us the next two to three weeks to build alongside your team. Once we have working use cases to show, I'd welcome the chance to walk you through what we've built and discuss whether this is the right path forward for the firm.

Regards,

Kurt

Legal Counsel, AutomateFlow

Thanks,

Client Services deep-dive with Sayde Whitaker and Kurt **Attendees**: Sayde (user@user), Kurt, Charles (user@user) **Key pain points confirmed with specifics**: 1. **Import/Export File Processing (TOP PRIORITY)**: FTP automation failing 3-4 times/week. Files not importing or not moving to correct locations. Creates distrust, requires daily manual verification. Same issues on exports. Goal: "out of sight, out of mind" with alerts only on failure. 2. **Media Movement**: 500-1,000 docs/day to clients. Manual process: Paper Vision → rename (PowerShell/Excel) → move to folders → zip → FTP. Clients complaining about delays, say competitors have this automated. 3. **Missing Media Tracking**: Legal filings require specific media, comes back in massive batches. No way to track if requested items received. ~1 hour/day manual checking across multiple spreadsheets, still backed up. Holding up demand letters 3-4 weeks, delaying revenue. **Future phases** (require internal cleanup first): Affidavit automation, reporting dashboards, SalesCloud integration **Technical context**: CLS (collection software), Paper Vision (doc storage), FTP servers, Excel/PowerShell macros **Next steps**: Sayde to send screenshots of current spreadsheets and processes SA request submitted to bring in technical support for scoping Schedule working session once materials received **Deal advancement**: Use cases now concrete enough to warrant SA engagement. This is the path to a $50K enterprise deal with real, quantifiable pain.
